results.abstract: Richard Woodward reviews book Lost Cosmonaut: Observations of an Anti-Tourist by Daniel Kalder; photo (M)

headline.main: Lost Cosmonaut: Observations of an Anti-Tourist

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: LOST COSMONAUT: OBSERVATIONS OF AN ANTI-TOURIST (BOOK)

results.snippet: This book is a half-facetious and mostly entertaining manifesto that takes place in the republics of the former Soviet Union.
results.lead_paragraph: By Daniel Kalder Scribner, 273 pages, $13 trade paperback Daniel Kalder is an existential tourist seething with Generation Y attitude, a smart-aleck Rimbaud who claims to gravitate toward the ''black holes'' on any map. Fed up with the yuppie travel network -- even the desolation of his native Scotland is too picturesque for his literary taste -- he seeks a more rarefied experience: the primal ennui of contemporary life, a reality shared by all if only we could, or dared to, pay attention.
